Vegan Leek Latkes Recipe | Bon Appétit




Skip to main contentOpen Navigation MenuMenuStory SavedTo revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories.Close AlertCloseStory SavedTo revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved storiesClose AlertCloseSign InSearchRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastMerch ShoprecipesDecember 2020 IssueVegan Leek LatkesBy Zak the BakerDecember 1, 20203.3(46)Read ReviewsTriangleEmailPinterestPrintPhotograph by Emma Fishman, prop styling by Elizabeth JaimeEmailPinterestPrintEmailPinterestPrintWith crisp outsides, creamy insides, and a subtle sweetness from tons of blanched leeks, these latkes from Zak the Baker might not be what you’re used to—and that’s a good thing. Most latkes are a lot of potato and a little bit of onion, but these are nearly half blanched leeks. And rather than grate raw potatoes, as you might for other latkes, you boil a single potato before blitzing it in a food processor along with the leeks, creating a finished texture that channels mashed potatoes. In place of egg, almond flour binds the mixture and also adds a touch of flavor you can’t put your finger on. Eat these with your hands (and tzatziki, if you don’t want to keep it vegan), and head here to read about why Zak the Baker wanted to highlight them this year for Hanukkah.IngredientsMakes 8-121large Yukon Gold potato (8–12 oz.), scrubbed1Tbsp. plus 1 tsp. Diamond Crystal 	or 2½ tsp. Morton kosher salt, divided; plus more2large leeks (about 1½ lb.), white and pale green parts only, sliced into ½"-thick rounds¼cup almond flour or meal¼cup Italian-style breadcrumbs1tsp. ground cuminFreshly ground black pepperVegetable oil (for frying; about 1¼ cups)Tzatziki (for serving)PreparationStep 1Preheat oven to 250°. Place potato and 1 Tbsp. Diamond Crystal or 2 tsp. Morton kosher salt in a medium pot; pour in cold water to cover. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce heat to medium and simmer until potato is fork-tender, 25–30 minutes total. Remove potato from pot; let cool slightly.Step 2Meanwhile, return water in pot to a boil. Add leeks and cook until very soft, about 5 minutes. Drain well.Step 3Using your hands, remove skin from potato; discard. Coarsely chop flesh. Transfer to a food processor and add leeks; pulse until chunky and well combined (it shouldn’t be homogeneous and smooth). Transfer mixture to a bowl. Add almond flour, breadcrumbs, cumin, and 1 tsp. Diamond Crystal or ½ tsp. Morton kosher salt, season with pepper, and mix well.Step 4Pour oil into a medium heavy skillet, preferably cast iron, to come ¼" up the sides; heat over medium-high. Working in batches of 3 or 4 and using a ¼-cup measure, scoop potato mixture into your hands and flatten into thin 3"-diameter disks. (Mixture may feel soft, but it will hold together.) Fry latkes, reducing heat if browning too quickly, until deep golden brown, about 4 minutes per side. Transfer to a wire rack set inside a rimmed baking sheet; season with salt. Keep warm in oven while you make remaining latkes. Serve with tzatziki.How would you rate Vegan Leek Latkes?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (13)Back to TopTriangleInstead of cumin I used caraway and they tasted fabulous! E ZinsserSouth Africa6/20/2021Sorry, I’m going back to a more traditional recipe (uncooked grated russets and egg). I carefully followed the recipe and ended up with very fragile cakes that left a third of the mix as blackened bits in the pan. No doubt there is some perfect combination of potato starch level, parboiling, moisture content, oil temp, etc that will make a perfect cake. I’m just not willing to cook this a dozen times to hopefully discern this magic formula. Eric WDurham, NC1/30/2021Is there a vegan tzatziki recipe? 
Anonymous1/15/2021I loved the flavor of these latkes.  They stayed together and did not fall apart, as happened to a previous reviewer.  They kind of reminded me of a knish but in the shape of a latke.  I am a big fan of traditional shredded potato and onion latkes but I will definitely add these to my rotation.  Yum!PaulSeattle, WA12/14/2020These were incredible, and so good reheated, too. I used red potatoes, and my second batch I added shallots, the mixture was less soft, but they didn't hold up as well when frying. The flavors are delicious though and will definitely make again.BrendaNew Jersey12/13/2020Delicious! Keep a few things in mind so they don't fall apart. Make sure not to overprocess the potatoes and leeks. Then use an icecream scoop and flatten them in your palm. If too liquid add some more almond flour and/or breadcrumbs.   No more than 4-5 in the pan. Fry them 4 minutes on one side, then flip them. I reheated them after 3 hrs in the air fryer at 360. Well worth the effort.Peter MoorWashington DC 12/12/2020There are two Zachs/Zaks: Zach Stern and Zak Polani. Two different people, two different spellings of the name.Anonymous12/9/2020Wish you included a Print button for recipes.TigerMOMissouri12/9/2020This isn't a review -- it's a comment. You published a photo with the caption "Zak the Baker a.k.a Zak Stearn" but I believe his correct last name is Stern (without an a). And to add insult to injury, you said in the text right below the photo caption that his name is ZaCH Polani. Are there two Zaks/Zachs?Marilyn ShortToronto, Canada12/9/2020These were delicious and perfect as written. Be patient and don’t crowd the pan.
